column4: why it is so difficult in linux to unrar unzip copy files and folders with many files :|
it is?
well, *i* do it via the terminal, *because* it can be much faster than any other way
if you aren't fond of that, i don't see what's wrong with file-roller (although being a KDE user, there might be a lot of things wrong with it that i don't know about)
wait, you're copying files into some place that you need root privileges to access? *why*?
and that's precisely, where? you do know you should never write outside of your home, /usr/local and /opt
anyway i don't see what makes it so slow. cd /directory/where/you/need/to/save ; sudo unrar x /path/and/file/to/the/rar/archive
there, done. and obviously you can use Tab to complete the pathnames, which makes that pretty fat.
no, you "must" not. you're doing something wrong if you are.
and why does playing quake3 involve writing to "forbidden" areas daily?
no, of course not. "~" means your home.
if you want to keep believing that, then keep beliving that. we're all telling you that you don't.

you can't see the . folders in Nautilus, the "." means precisely that they're hidden folders. you can see them in the shell, and you also should be able to point Nautilus to them if you type the name in.
you can also convert monkey's audio to other formats, but no program to do that is available in the repositories - you'd have to look somewhere on the web.
monkey's audio is proprietary, so the original decoder can't be included, and it's difficult to reverse engineer one
you should use something else - like FLAC - if at all possible
say again?
synaptic is always installed by default on an Ubuntu desktop install.
if you original question made no sense, and it didn't, others aren't to blame.
more or less. you have a non-networked computer, you have used the "Generate package download script" feature of Synaptic, and you want to transfer the resulting file to another computer?
so you need to install ndiswrapper-utils from the CD? you just need to put the CD in, type "sudo apt-cdrom add", and then type "sudo apt-get install ndiswrapper-utils"
i don't know. but i do know that Synaptic couldn't find any better than apt-get can
still wireless network list is empty :|
installing ndiswrapper is certainly not enough, you need to install the driver too
